utterances: Ghani says the two candidates have agreed to the most thorough audit in the history of any election.
Abdullah says that the candidates forged an additional agreement.
(SOUNDBITE OF PRESS CONFERENCE)
We also have a framework of national unity government once the ballot papers are claimed.
Abdullah and Ghani say that whoever is declared the winner will immediately form a broad and inclusive government, though they provided no details on how power would be divided.
The audit will take weeks to complete, and President Karzai has agreed to push back the inauguration ceremony originally scheduled for August 2.
Sean Carberry, NPR News, Kabul.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
Im Neal Conan in Washington.

Every Wednesday, NPR Political editor Ken Rudin joins us to talk politics.

A 14-term House incumbent loses a Democratic primary in West Virginia, Jimmy Carter's grandson is now State Senator Jason Carter in Georgia, the SEIU elects a new president, even more fallout from Bondagegate, the ad war escalates in Pennsylvania.
That primary comes up next week, along with Arkansas, Oregon and Kentucky.
We'll talk with Bluegrass Staters Rand Paul and Trey Grayson, the big rivals for the Republican Senate nomination.
Later this hour, privacy protests hit Facebook, but first, political junkie Ken Rudin joins us here in Studio 3A, as he does every Wednesday.
As usual, we begin with a trivia question.
Hey, Ken.
Hi, Neal.
Okay, exciting times coming up, big primaries next week, and one of the big primaries, of course, is Arlen Specter.
He is -of course, he switched parties last year.
I think he was a Republican, although I'm not...
Yeah, he was originally a Democrat.
Yeah, exactly.

This is, this is, you know, it's really, it's unclear, I mean, the al-Qaeda training manuals, and, and, and their tradecraft, you know, their spycraft is that they're allowed, you know, they're very, they say they're very devout, and they're doing this as a route to heaven, and to serve their notion of jihad, which many of them equate with worship, but, apparently, they're given some sort of operational leeway to appear undercover, and sort of enjoy the fruits of this world.

Saqa, this guy had, yeah, the people in this apartment saw him with this, you know, young girl, and, and he had a wife and kids back in Syria he'd been visiting before, so it's not entirely clear what was going on, but he looked like he was, it looked like he was enjoying his work there toward the end.
Mm-hmm.

Now, in, in terms of his, you know, his activities, one of the things that people have wondered a lot about was the extent of contact, and, you know, intermingling between the old al-Qaeda, if you will, the people who, you know, met in Afghanistan, and went to camps there, and Osama bin Laden.
And Mr. Zarqawi, who's, of course, in Iraq, a Jordanian, and sort of a the new al- Qaeda.
This was a man, al-Saqa, who played in both camps.
Yeah, he seemed to.
It's a little bit fuzzy, and it may be a deliberate fuzziness, but, for instance, in the Istanbul bombings, which al- Saqa apparently described some roll in, and then has, and now disavows.
But, it appears that he got $50,000 of the $150,000 dollars from Zarqawi that, this was money that financed the four truck bombs a couple of years ago, here.
And the rest seems to have come from al-Qaeda and from Saudi sympathizers to al-Qaeda that he delivered.
The plot itself, though clearly Zarqawi knew about it, but he was not yet with al-Qaeda.
He's now with a group called al-Qaeda in Iraq.
But remember, about a year and a half ago, it was very significant when he announced that he was now part of al-Qaeda, and pledging fealty to Osama bin Laden.

But the original Istanbul plot, and the idea to strike Turkey was something that bin Laden himself had in August 2001, about a month before 9-11-- specifically, personally authorized to some of the plotters.
So, yeah, you're right.

There's sort of these, this network, these sort of intermingling grids, where sometimes they overlap in making common cause, and even operationally, and sometimes they're just at all points in the same direction.
Also, this man revealed all these details about his life after long interrogation by Turkish authorities.
Are we to believe everything he says?
A lot of it lines up.
The Turks believe a lot of it.
He is, as I say, he said a lot of things, and then declined to sign the statement on the advice of his attorney, who the Turkish authorities are trying to implicate.
A lot of what he says checks out.
I've talked to people who go in and out of Fallujah who had heard of him, who said he was there and known as a pretty senior person with Zarqawi.
He was indicted along with Zarqawi for the millennium plot, which was supposed to destroy an Amman hotel, and target some tourist sites visited by Christians on December 31st, 2000, or 1999.
And, so, a lot of what he--and he's implicated by other people who are now standing trial on the Istanbul bombing.
So, yeah, it does, by and large, what he says does seem to be corroborated by other circumstances and testimonies.
Including by, as you mentioned earlier, by his own lawyer.
Yes.
His lawyer is definitely of the same beliefs.

He's a, you know, he's a bearded guy who's got, who handles a lot of Islamist clients, and who is, describes himself as, basically, a radical Muslim, who's a member in good standing in the bar, and who is very careful to stay within the law here.
And who had spent a fair amount of time within his, you know, rational and straightforward person, and talked about how al-Saqa, wants to, sort of, talk straight.
But, for reasons that aren't entirely clear, he's gone a little bit back and forth on what he will admit to in court, and to what's legally binding.
I assume that there's some concern about betraying other operations, or an organization, the al-Qaeda organization, but it's not quite clear why he's leaning both ways.
And that leads to another question, which is, has his information been made available to American authorities who may want to know what he knows about what's going on inside Iraq?

Yeah, I know that, according to his lawyer and reports in the Turkish press, at least once, I think twice, CIA, people who are assumed to be CIA, American Intelligence people have been to his prison cell in, where he's being held in a high-security place in Istanbul, and have talked to him.
And I'm told that they got along well, that their approach to him was gentlemanly and business-like, and was appreciated.
I don't know if he said, I don't know what he told them, you know, that's where we are.
How much do we know about, one of the things he wrote about was his experience as, sort of as a commander during the first battle of Fallujah, if you will.
What more do we know about what he did there?
He did, you know, you might remember, there were two assaults on Fallujah.
The first was in March or April 2004, and it was after those contractors were attacked and cut up, and their bodies were burned and hung on that bridge, and everyone was outraged.
And someone, I think, the story is that President Bush himself worked an offensive in retaliation to that.
It got so far, and at the same time, the Shiites were starting their insurgency in the south, and that defensive was called off.
But during that time, al-Saqa showed up with some other people from Turkey.
He then stayed while Fallujah became, you know, really, an insurgent town, and Zarqawi was one of the people sort of running the place.

And, in that time, he was a fairly senior commander, I mean, I don't know what his field abilities are, but he was somebody who was, according to former fighters, calling in coordinates for border attacks on U.S.
bases around Iraq, and played a big role in what was a fairly significant attack on Abu Ghraib prison.
Don't.
Please don't do that - and a member of the House.
But -and he was the last president, elected president who served as governor and House member but not senator.
But he is not the last nominee.
Let's go to Ramona(ph), Ramona with us from Philly.

And finally, let me ask you, if he'd been involved in what you describe as running these rat lines, you know, getting operatives and money and, you know, identity cards and that sort of thing to various people and various places, have Turkish authorities been able to follow up on his information and roll up other members of the organization?
This is something, the short answer to that is, I don't know.
When they found this burned out apartment, among the things that survived the fire was about seven false ID's, including a couple of Tunisian passports, all, with his picture in them.
He was really good at this, and this was what he'd been doing in Turkey since 1998.
Since, Turkey has always been, because of where it is geographically, a real crossroads for everyone going all over this region.
And, he was someone who facilitated that with these false ID's.
And he gets people in and out through Syria.
He's from northern Syria, which is the, sort of, preferred route for people, for fighters trying to join.
Even if you're coming from Saudi Arabia, which also borders Iraq, people are, Saudis are going up into Syria to come in to establish routes.
And he was quite expert at that.
Yeah.
Yeah.
Karl Vick, thanks very much.
We appreciate your time.
It's my pleasure.
Thank you.
Karl Vick, foreign correspondent for the Washington Post, speaking with us from Istanbul.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION, from NPR News.
